column1: After I had rested from the dangers of my third voyage
column2: my passion for trade and my love of novelty soon again prevailed. I therefore settled my affairs
column3: and provided a stock of goods fit for the traffic I designed to engage in. I took the route of Persia
column5: and then arrived at a port
column6: where I embarked. On putting out to sea
column7: we were overtaken by such a sudden gust of wind as obliged the captain to lower his yards and take all other necessary precautions to prevent the danger that threatened us. But all was in vain; our endeavors had no effect; the sails were split into a thousand pieces
column8: and the ship was stranded; several of the merchants and seamen were drowned
column9: and the cargo was lost.I had the good fortune
column10: with several of the merchants and mariners
column12: and we were carried by the current to an island which lay before us. There we found fruit and spring water
column13: which preserved our lives. We stayed all night near the place where we had been cast ashore.
